We have been made aware of a number of privately sponsored dances being planned throughout the valley during the next few weeks as replacements for the Homecoming dances that will not be held at local high schools. These dances are not sponsored nor endorsed by the Logan City School District.

Unfortunately, when large-scale gatherings of this type have taken place across the state, these events have often resulted in spikes in the number of positive cases of COVID-19.

We recognize the desires of students and parents to have these events, and we will continue to do all we can to safely provide as many traditional activities and events as we can throughout the school year.

In order to keep schools open, and limit the number of student quarantines, we encourage students and community members to continue to follow health and safety guidelines that have allowed our community to manage COVID-19 as well as we have up to this point.

At the Board Meeting held last night, the Board, guided by the data, opinions, and thoughts of the community, decided to move forward with the following:

All schools in the Logan City School District will return to a full-day schedule with all students attending each day. Lunch, recess, and other traditional elements of the day will be provided according to each school’s schedule. Detailed school schedules will be forthcoming.

The school day for all K-12 schools will be shortened by 45 minutes in order to provide time for teachers to complete tasks related to managing online learning opportunities for students.

There will be no late start Wednesdays built into any school schedule.

El 21 de julio, el Concilio de Educación de LCSD aprobó un plan para la "apertura suave" de las escuelas. El plan prescribe que todos los estudiantes matriculados asisten a la escuela durante solo una parte del día, ya sea en la tarde de la mañana. Kindergarten y preescolar continuarán en sus horarios normales. Se continuará brindando transporte a todos los estudiantes que vivan en un vecindario elegible para el autobús, y se servirán comidas escolares durante ambas sesiones.

Intentaremos crear horarios que funcionen para cada familia. Para ayudar con eso, utilice esta encuesta para decirnos si prefiere que sus estudiantes asistan a la escuela durante las sesiones de AM o PM.

Complete esta encuesta para cada uno de sus hijos que asistirán a la escuela en persona en cualquier escuela (primaria o escuela secundaria). Estudiantes matriculados en el program de LCSD Online no asistirán a la escuela durante los medio días y no deben participar en esta encuesta.

Comuníquese con el distrito escolar al 435-755-2300 si tiene alguna pregunta.

On July 21, the LCSD Board of Education approved a plan for the soft opening of all schools. The plan includes all enrolled students attending school for a half-day, either in the morning or afternoon. Kindergarten and preschool will continue on their normal schedules. Busing will continue to be provided to all students who live in a bus-eligible neighborhood, and school meals will be served during both sessions.

We will attempt to create schedules that work for each family. In order to help with that, please use this survey to tell us if you prefer that your students attend school during the AM or PM sessions.

Please complete this survey for each of your children who will be attending school in person at any school (elementary, middle, and high). Students enrolled in LCSD Online will not need to attend school during the half-days, and should not complete this survey.

Please contact the school district at 435-755-2300 with any questions.

We know that many of our students and their families have been affected by the demonstrations across our country, protesting racist violence. We recognize that those protests are motivated by deep seated frustration due to a long history of violence and discrimination against ethnic minorities in our country.

The Logan City School District, and each of our employees, is committed to providing an environment free of racist policies, practices, speech, and behavior. We are committed to examining our own practices to ensure every student has access to a safe, supportive learning experience, free of discrimination and inequity.

We are committed to becoming more actively antiracist.

To our students and their families who may be suffering right now: we love you and value you. If there is more we can do to support you, now and in the future, please let us know by contacting your teacher, your principal, or by contacting my office.

Sincerely,

Superintendent Frank Schofield

The announcements have been made and we are thrilled to share that Taylor Fang, Logan High senior, has been named a U.S. Presidential Scholar. She is one of three students in the state of Utah to receive this award. Additionally, Mr. Drew Nielsen has been selected by this same organization as a Distinguished Teacher having been nominated by Taylor.

The U.S. Presidential Scholars Program was established in 1964, by executive order of the President, to recognize and honor some of our nation's most distinguished graduating high school seniors. In 1979, the program was extended to recognize students who demonstrate exceptional talent in the visual, creative and performing arts. In 2015, the program was again extended to recognize students who demonstrate ability and accomplishment in career and technical education fields. Each year, up to 161 students are named as Presidential Scholars, one of the nation's highest honors for high school students.

Congratulations Taylor and Mr. Nielsen! You make #teamlogan strong!

While learning is looking different right now, students are still excelling. Groups of 5th grade students at Woodruff Elementary took part in the virtual Thermo Fisher Scientific Applied Science Solutions competition. This year's theme was Environmental Stability that would benefit Cache Valley. The students were asked to think creatively about a problem within Cache Valley and work together as a team to design a solution.

They began this project in December and designed a greenhouse at the school that could provide people access to fresh foods, the opportunity to learn how to work and plant, boost mental health, and create a better environment. Their idea was that our school would act as a pilot program and then we'd provide the procedure to other schools within Cache Valley to do it as well. The students even 3D printed a greenhouse model for it! They placed first place and won $3000.

An additional team did a project on traffic and road congestion and took 5th place and won $500.

Congratulations to these students who persevered through the entire project and presentation.

The Bear River Health Department has prepared some information for the community. These are messages they feel are specific to our community and will help with all of the COVID-19 measures that we are taking. We appreciate all that they are doing to help keep us safe and healthy.

"As the escalating threat of the coronavirus pandemic continues we are pleading with families to protect their older relatives, such as grandparents, and other family members with serious underlying medical conditions. To do so, we are asking to postpone visits or trips to see these family members. Instead, write letters, make phone calls or connect through technology. Please limit your children's contact with these high-risk populations. We must protect our most vulnerable! If your child were to develop the illness their symptoms might be mild but for these vulnerable populations, it can be life-threatening. If we take these precautions seriously we will not exhaust our hospital's capacity to care for the ill."

As many of you may have seen, the school dismissal has been extended through May 1st by Governor Herbert.

A few quick items to note:

1. We will continue with our scheduled Spring Break from March 30 - April 3rd.

2. Instruction will continue for all students following Spring Break. You will be receiving a phone call, if you haven’t already, regarding the accessibility of technology in your home. Following Spring Break, we will be distributing Chromebooks to families in need. The details of this distribution process will be given as firm plans are finalized. Our technology team is working hard to create a smooth distribution plan.

3. Additionally, our Child Nutrition Services department is working to determine what the plan will be for school lunches. Distribution will continue as planned for this week and details regarding distribution following Spring Break will be forthcoming.

This is a very fluid situation and we commit to sharing details as soon as we have them. We hope you are all safe and healthy,

March 18, 2020 update:

It was refreshing to see so many smiling faces this morning across the District. Thank you to our Child Nutrition crew for preparing so many lunches, thank you to the school staff and volunteers for their preparations to make distribution of food and learning so seamless, and thank you to our wonderful families and students for your smiles, kind words and patience during these uncertain times.

A few items to note:

4. All offices, schools and District, will be available via phone from 9 am-12 pm Monday - Friday during the dismissal.
4. Feel free to visit https://www.loganschools.org/covid19-information to find answers to frequently asked questions.

Safe safe, stay healthy and keep reading everyday!!
